please welcome Gavin Jackson managing director UK and Ireland at Amazon Web
Services [Music] [Applause]
thank you good morning and welcome to AWS transformation Day 2018 this is the
second time we've run an event in this format actually in this very room and it's not your typical AWS technology
deep dive today we're going to be talking at a slightly different altitude we're gonna be talking about
transformation we're going to be talking about change and the observations and
the trends that we see which means the businesses are going to have to change and transition to a completely different
operating model and how IT is aligned to that operating model now one of the big
questions that I like to ask customers I see a lot of customers on my travels is if you could change one thing what would
it be and it's amazing how consistent actually the results that you get back the same answers time and time again and it's
captured really well in this quote from a real-life CEO of a UK headquartered
manufacturing company multinational who said if we can go back to day one we
would make ourselves systemically innovative if we could go back to day
one we would make ourselves systemically innovative I just think that's such a powerful statement and such a powerful
kind of assessment of what we hear time and time again from our customers and that it's almost easier to imagine going
back to the start than it is to actually transform which i think is half the battle here and so it's also very well
aligned to how our founder and CEO Jeff Bezos thinks about the culture at Amazon and he says that there are day one
companies and there are day two companies and day two is stasis followed
by irrelevance followed by painful decline and finally death so when that
cheery note have a great day I'll see you later but of course you know what
Jeff actually means is that change is perpetual motion' it happens every day
it never stops and customers are always going to want better so really what day
one means is optimizing for customers and optimizing for better
and not getting stuck in a number of these sort of the pitfalls and the traps that you see from from day two companies
typically so today is really about giving you some ideas and even a pathway
to how you should think about culture how you should think about the organizational structure of your
business how you think about the operating model and then finally the the actual technology platform itself to
become a day one business that is systemically innovative but without having to invent a time machine to go
back to day one in order to make that happen so why is this important this is
a quote for financial services but it actually is a lot broader than this it's just a quote I like it's from McKinsey &
Co and it said the banks aren't being disrupted by FinTech companies they're being disrupted by customer expectations
that's absolutely correct expectations have gone through the roof is just being served by multitude of different
companies now and we're experiencing what I refer to as the great unbundling
of the world where we see sort of thousands of day one companies that are picking apart at the seams and at the
edges you know parts of the incumbent businesses that they're living that space one business process one app and
one customer experience at a time and it's happened in an exponential rates of change and of course it's not just banks
that are being disrupted in this ways all industries is all companies in all walks of life where insurgent companies
are kind of exploiting underserved or so the latent customer dissatisfaction and doubling down at the rate of change that
has never been seen before and oftentimes it's too late then for the incumbent companies to sort of keep up and of course you can cross out banks as
I've suggested here you can cross out banks about any company in there you can cross out the pretext of FinTech and you
can put your sort of pretext in there for ad Tech or Mar Tech or travel Tech or game tech or health tech or you name
it Tech it's happening everywhere the world as we know it is being broken
apart and reassembled in the form of software and software changes a very
different rate to the physical world like factories and we refer to this as
the accelerated metabolism of business is where your industries and business sort of adopt the speed of change that
technology has and has an exponential curve so really what companies need to
ask themselves is what kind of factory do you need to build when software is eating the world and we think that it's
software factories they need to build and that they're in the cloud where the production line workers are the builders
and the DevOps teams and the machines and the robots and the AI and the data and the infra infrastructure technology
platform is all in the cloud with AWS so
what kind of attributes does this new software factory world enable well the
first thing is now it allows for exponentially more experiments if you think about it today before the cloud
you have to take the whole round trip on a business case for any kind of new idea you have to go to your finance teams to
get approval for sign off on your things you just can't you imagine the size and the scope of the of the project being
you have to go through procurement loops for hardware and software you have to play the perpetual guessing game as to
how big is going to be is it going to be a hit is it going to be a miss and so actually turns out just to be too hard and so experiment rates go down and in
the cloud the cost of experimentation is virtually zero and it happens in an instance and this freedom then allows
you to exponentially add more experiments which leads to greater successes you kill your failures really
fast you double down an auto scale on your successes and in doing so you give yourself a dramatic competitive
advantage the London School of Economics actually did a study on this very point and they said that companies that
deliver a devops operating model in the AWS cloud have it between 500 and 2,000
percent faster time-to-market than those that don't that's a 5x to 20x
advantage by deploying devops in a diverse cloud is just dramatic and speed matters when software is king and
it really is one of the key differences between day 1 and day 2 company mentalities
but at the same time the cloud is also having a profound of profound effects on the technologies around it the other
mega trends that we see if you think about machine learning and AI for instance these are essentially just
massive compute and data problems that we're trying to solve and they used to be just this sort of in the domains of
research universities like MIT or Cambridge or something like that but because of the cloud and because of the
AWS tooling that we're giving to people it's now available to anyone and everyone and so now everyone has the
opportunity to use machine learning to automate their processes to add sort of precision to their data models and their
and their data problems to build new AI interfaces with voice and with computer vision and other such programs and to
just build and reinvent the customer experience it's now available to everybody according to PwC AI will add
two hundred and thirty two billion pounds with a GDP in the UK over the next ten years and according to IDC 40%
of all digital transformations will be aided by artificial intelligence these
are really important business signals that you should capture as part of that change that's happening and I can tell
you that today is the day that you should get on board of all of those now of course the world building software is
a full-contact multiplayer game it's no longer about the big sort of incumbent company versus the big rival it's scores
of insurgent companies that are attacking from all different angles and that's because in the cloud the barriers
to entry to start and run a new business are so low you can be up and running and build a new business attacking just a
weaker point within the customer experience and be up and running very quickly but the same is true for
incumbent companies for enterprises to reinvent the customer experience so it
really is a level playing field it's about who is going to capture that latent dissatisfaction with customers
first and fastest so it really is about
survival of the fittest the fastest and the most adaptable and that really does
mean the day one companies have an outsized advantage I always say that you can't work off a
bad diet right that you can't exercise digital and then carry on consuming high-calorie technology you have to find
a way of shedding the pounds if you're going to continue to be fast and agile and to capture those new customer experiences in that same study with a
London School of Economics they showed that companies that are sort of decluttering from the previous world
of sort of legacy technology have up to a 90% operating cost advantage over those
that don't and that when you add the kind of 5 to 20x time to market
improvements that you can get because of the cloud the absolute output the absolute productivity gain that most
companies get is on average 20 percent higher than their peers this really is game changing almost
table stakes however for business tomorrow but just as fast as day one
companies are sort of progressing an exponential rate it actually has the reverse effect on incumbents to stand
still and you can start to see this when you compare we're gonna get into more detail or along these lines in one of
the next third talks but you can start to see this when you compare some of the
attributes of day one companies and day 2 companies so I'll give you for instance so day 1 companies you really
kind of focus on the customer problem they're trying to solve and they really index on achieving better and once they
found better they try and disprove what better looks like an A they try to find better again whereas day 2 companies
tend to sort of double down and profit for the long term as to what they've got and they forget often times that the
customer journey is changing and they don't necessarily always change with it your day one companies make high
velocity decisions and they iterate and change very very quickly day two companies tend to make high-quality
decisions and it's all data driven but it just takes too long to get those decisions past and through various
different parts of the organization and then the customer expectation has moved on it's too late your day one companies
do everything they can to harvest as much power from data as they possibly
can to learn from their customers to index on on what and anticipate what they're gonna want
net1 next whereas day two companies have what I refer to as a data phobia right
that's caused by yeah the the fear of security breaches or of regulatory
compliance or some other thing that builds a fear a phobia almost as to how
you can use data to your advantage and then finally day one companies are
voracious consumers of new technology and they see it as giving them the edge right they say they want to get their
business into software as fast as they can they want to hit those exponential curves of progress that you get when
companies and industries move into technology and day 2 companies they tend to fear some of those changes and
oftentimes are surrounded by your frankly old guard technology companies who profit from keeping you standing
still the good news is you don't need to invent a time machine to go back to day
one day one starts today and just to prove that I'd like to bring out my
first guest for today I'd like to invite the director for cloud practice at KPMG Chris Ashley Chris
[Music] [Applause]
how's it go okay Chris so you want to
tell me just a little bit about you and your team and what your team do at KPMG show up so high Chris I said I lead the
cloud practice and I was thinking is bit of a weird term actually to say leave the cloud practice what would a client practice be and I'm definitely not in
order to have figured that out from being a KPMG but what I'm actually here to do now for KPMG is to grow a
capability for our business to enable the business to transform themselves through leveraging cloud and what I think's been really interesting for us
is is what we've achieved over the past couple of years the last two years we've tripled the size of the team both years
have gone from ten to thirty then 30 to 90 I'm anticipate similar level of growth this year so the demand really is there
for the kind of things we do it's amazing life yeah so what why did KPMG feel the need to do any kind of
transformation at all well first it was all about agility it really was we had an on-premises facility that was failing
us it didn't allow us to iterate fast enough and and we had genuine failures in that facility as well and we saw
cloud as a way to solve both of those problems and it really did so it reduced the risk of the existing facility
massively had a lot less failures and it enabled our business to build new services for our customers apace which
was the real thing we're after yeah excellent and what's been the overall sort of business productivity impact of
that transformation so I think I think the main thing pros is the speed with which we can get to market so our first
project was it was kind of simple project it was our tax advisory services
as a service and that project took as nine months to build out get it through governance risk IT security everything
like that our record today is ten days so we've managed to make a 27 X improvement and our ability to build
services for our clients so things amazing.you that's really cool and how's AWS enabled that that change in their
changing customer experience well I said that the main way is that the type of offerings that we aren't now able to
offer so we can now take entire solutions to market and give our customers an outcome on those solutions
so as a consultant practice and previously we would often advise our clients on how to solve problems what we
can do now is we can actually build that solution for them as well as to take them all the way through that lifecycle
and give them that value at the end and that's really open there's a a lot of new opportunities and opportunities that
KPMG certainly wouldn't have had in our marketplace before and that certain impacts through pre-sales post sales as
well so we can demo solutions to clients as part of trying to get them to understand how we're going to help and
that's open new lines of businesses that we were the wouldn't have had in the past yeah absolutely and what about so I
mentioned earlier on about this little boon in machine learning artificial intelligence cetera so are you sorry you
finding the customers are adopting those sort of technologies and how are you helping them so it's really interesting actually because what our clients are
saying to us is they've got a business imperative they're trying to solve and they're trying to either move faster or
they're trying to solve problems in different way whatever it is and one of the main things they're trying to do
there is enable their data science community to get working on their data yeah and so as a result we we would
propose some solutions at a de beste have already built for them solutions like recognition and sage maker interest and that that's really allowed those
businesses to move much much faster yeah so it's not about necessarily they're not asking us for those services but the fact that they're already there and able
to be leveraged very very quickly that's what's bringing the value excellent so I also made the assertion earlier on that their culture plays a big part in
innovation so how are you addressing the sort of culture of innovation at KPMG so well in an organization like ours and I
expect a lot of the organizations here today this is by far the biggest challenge you know I would say people
are way more complex than machines and getting them to to make this transition is is definitely the thing that's that's
there's been a big struggle for us however we started small and the same ways we did with our first project so
and we start small we built on it and now we've got a culture of working at pace we're following agile methodologies
and really focusing on our clients so taking that idea of listening to our customers and sending what they want and
working backwards from that yeah and that has really transformed our business that's awesome and if you could give sort of one piece of advice to the
people in the audience here about how to get started what would you say so it's a start with a simple single project right
so take take that first project and start delivering value to the business really really quickly as fast as you can
really and make that as much of what you'd built for this project reusable on subsequent projects that's gonna be
really helpful for you and that'll allow you to grow as we've done is having hundreds of workloads in public cloud
yeah so just don't for cloud navona from the beginning because it doesn't exist try and build
something in add value really yeah that's really good advice Chris thank you very much for spending some time with us so I appreciate the partnership
as always thank you thanks very much that's good so we've been seeing over
the course of the last number of years back to their sort of theme of exponential exponential growth in the
demand for those types of skills that your businesses need in order to you kind of really realized the benefits of
cloud and this new operating model as I stand here today there are 15,000 831
permanent jobs in the UK and Ireland that specify AWS as being a core
competency that's almost 10 percent of the total jobs market and there's a further eight and a half thousand
contractors they'll also specify this requirement we just simply aren't
producing enough technical talent to satisfy the need that we all have here to be successful as the last year we
announced a program with the Prince's Trust and with the ministry defense called AWS restart and the idea of that
is to to capture people that otherwise wouldn't make it into technology to give them the training that they need in
order to make a difference and contribute to the world of technology and I'm pleased to say that the 80 bus restart program is going great guns and
we're really delighted at the the response from companies like KPMG and direct-line who are here in the audience
audience and a number of other companies who are participating and partnering with us when they give us restart I did
really wish for you to go and speak to the folks in the training booth to find
out more about how you can participate in AWS restart because it really is making a difference it's not going to be
the Nirvana to solve all of those open jobs that are out there but it is going to make a difference and I don't
encourage you to get involved the other thing that we're doing this year with the Prince's Trust is we're participating in the million makers
program which is essentially the technology industry trying to raise a million pounds for the Prince's Trust to
again help more people get back into into technology from the get-go so we
have a Prince's Trust in AWS booth outside as well so to encourage you to go speak to the folks
there and see how we can get involved in sort of competing for things like reinvent tickets or we have Grand Tour
filming if you're familiar with the Grand Tour we have we have tickets to the Grand Tour filming as well which is sort of money can't buy that types of
prizes so go visit the booth out there and and get yourselves involved in that
so before I hand over I just want to go back and revisit this quote from from
Jeff Bezos that there are day one companies and there are day two companies and we all know how day two
ends and that's why we always say Amazon it's always day one but the point I really want to emphasize here is that
for all companies it ought to be a mindset of day one your customers are
always dissatisfied and we should always index on what we want next and so being day one is about optimizing
for that and that only and to help sort of progress the story further I'd like
now to introduce our next speaker our keynote speaker the director for enterprise strategy AWS Miriam McLemore

good morning oh come on good morning I'm
thrilled to have the opportunity to be here with you today I am now an
enterprise strategist for AWS but I spend the bulk of my career at the coca-cola company
I was the corporate CIO I spent 26 years at coca-cola so quite quite the journey
I started my career there in finance it's been about four years in the global marketing team a couple of years in our
North America business and then the final dozen as part of IT and when I
retired from coca-cola at the end of 2016 I had responsibility for a broad
range of technologies I had all things customer and consumer facing so all 600
brand websites everything mobile all of our large experiences like the Olympics
World Cup Euro Cup the Superbowl those kind of large customer consumer

technologies that at coca-cola bean over a hundred and thirty years old was a lot
of legacy great and lots of challenges to move that speed coca-cola's largely a
youth brand and focused on youth and really bringing the next generation into
the franchise and so that focus of coca-cola meant that you had to be
current you had to feel like an innovative company and so that challenge
in an IT environment where you've had such a heavy legacy to deal with was

that and a little bit about just the journey most enterprises I now
get because run around the world and speak to large enterprises about the challenges we face as Enterprise leaders
to become what Gavin was just describing which is a day one company so you know
change is hard we have high customer and
consumer expectations certainly at coca-cola you had to be current you had to be relevant in the market and so we
often as part of the marketing organization talking about right message right time right consumer right in real
time how do you do that how does IT enable that messaging well very low
barriers to entry in the beverage industry all sorts of beverages you look

quality distribution all of the things that come with a brand like coca-cola so

environment from a tech standpoint from an equipment standpoint from an
ingredient standpoint just constant change food law changes all over the
world I had responsibility for everything Rd for the company so having our brands be consistent with food laws
all over the world was part of the system so I had all of our product lifecycle management systems as well so
that was the world that Weaver in and you were in as large enterprises and you
know what I experienced put together a little list of the things we were challenged with and the things we wanted to become right we were challenged with
slow delivery cycles within IT I'm trying to deliver promotions in market
and I needed fast time to market euro cups gonna happen on the day it happens I could not be delayed by a PMO
process in IT that was gonna say oh well that project you're gonna have to wait
we're gonna deliver it in a month no that's not gonna work out well in markets so getting where we could
deliver at speed and Gavin talk about speed matters effort spent in the wrong
areas we always had the too many people working on legacy problems P ones P
zeros where we wanted to be moving thinking about the new decisions working
toward the future versus just running the environment that we had created and
that was a big part of creating that environment so no no blame cast on anyone right I was there quite a long
time silos and gatekeepers that for me
was one of the biggest struggles we had to go through the procurement process
the legal process the finance process the business planning process right and
process really became the enemy to progress and it was interesting
throughout my career we spent time and I actually started my career at Arthur Andersen and companies of Accenture
today and you know we would say companies need to be more process driven
it's interesting I come to Amazon and Jeff Bezos says process is the often the
enemy of business outcome because the process can become the thing and I very
much experience that throughout my career where oh we check the box we ran the process we did the PMO process we
did the procurement process but did we focus on the business outcome that we
were trying to achieve an enabling collaboration across the system coca
course operates in 209 countries across 32 major markets so gigging
collaboration being able to reuse and move technology capabilities promotions
markets market was essential to the company to reduce cost and to operate at the
speed fear of change certainly within my team I had a globally distributed team
had a dev Center in the Philippines one in istanbul one in brussels one mexico and of course a large team in atlanta
georgia the home of coca-cola and there was a lot of fear cultural resistance of
that changes and the future and what are you doing to me I was there 26 years
there many people at coca-cola longer than I I just went to a retirement party
for someone 35 years at the company when you have that longevity at a company it
is very difficult to get people to change and we needed to be focused on
what our customers wanted what our consumers are expecting certainly and I
talked about processes we had change resistant processes we those you know
kind of ruled and trying to unwind those processes I had responsibilities for HR
and HR was was a one of the challenging functions we had an on-prem ASAP HR
system with 92 other legacy HR applications and I was responsible for
picking all of that up and moving to workday so HR data in the cloud that was
a big move for the company and a big just cultural change and then like the
HR environment huge amount of legacy and the need for innovation so that was kind
of our what we were and where we wanted to get and I want to take you through
some of the the things that you know it feels like bad news for an enterprise
but I don't think it's bad news I'd loved working for the coca-cola company I had some fabulous experiences all over
the world and you need to recognize as enterprises the things that you have
what are the value elements to your
organization obviously deep knowledge of your market coca-cola
understood markets at a street level highly skilled and committed employees
financial resources we talked about startups having great the startups are the ones that are in the great position
enterprises have the financial resources and the customer base and the brand
equity that startups dream of when started to get audience with anybody at
coca-cola they were just thrilled and so remembering what your advantages are we
often talked about at coke how do we digitize the vast physical assets that
the company has how do we make them part of our future and our solution coke cats
on the road more trucks and vehicles and FedEx and UPS combined 14 million pieces
of equipment out and market that people touch on a regular basis how do you
leverage that from a digital standpoint in the world today and so there are the
processes that are in your way but there are also things like coke supply chain that was a huge benefit the ability to
get a product spread all over the world in a month is an absolute advantage and
so being clear on your advantages and and something else I liked about what
Gavin said I think enterprises forgot often that they have innovation in their
DNA Cooke was a start-up right it was a cough syrup the pharmacy is in Atlanta
where it moved from being a medicinal product to a beverage cook was a startup
getting the distribution for coke was a one handshake deal $1 spend partnership
with McDonald's handshake deal these were startup mindsets that to me
it's more about regaining that DNA regaining a focus on the
things that make you different the things that are the value statements of your organization and then pairing that
with the technology and the capabilities that exist in market today and I get
change is hard right the established processes we talked about cultural
resistance is huge existing infrastructure is a challenge and I had
the opportunity to live through all of those challenges so I put together a short list of things that I think that
get you started at least got us started at coca-cola so hopefully you find it
helpful because the goal is to unblock innovation and take advantage of your
strengths right that's all what we were trying to do at least at the coca-cola
company and across the system but it is to me at the end of the day an
organizational challenge with an embedded technology challenge but the
tech really works it's about giving the organization to leverage it in the right
way to build value for your organization so here's my little starter list
hopefully helpful to you so in order to transform I think the first thing you've
got to do is gain technical flexibility and speed you've got to organize as
smaller independent teams my workday team started out with you know 150
people it's very hard to get anything done when it's a hundred and fifty
people so we broke it down into the functions so we had a learning management team and we had a core data
team and we had a comp and bin team so once we broke it down into its core components we began to pick up momentum
agile and lean practices we all know that but training your team gaining
experience in agile and lean and training your business teams um what
does that mean are my consumer team you know doing
sprints with our business partners to prepare an experience for the Olympics
was a training process to get the business team on board because you can't
do it without your business partners so agile and lean investing in strategic
capabilities AWS was a big partner for me as well from a marketing standpoint
we leveraged Adobe pretty broadly moving to the cloud and I'll talk about cookies
journey here in a and a little bit to the cloud and what we move first and how we moved and then getting the data
strategy in place my role when I was part of the marketing organization was to leave business intelligence for the
company globally and we all know today that data is the currency and you've got
to get a clear data strategy in place so
second thing so technical flexibility and speed an environment of innovation
and this is where to me the culture really comes to the front first thing
you have to do and we needed to do at coca-cola is lower the cost of failure
no one's going to invent on your behalf no one's going to take you to the future
if when they screw up or something doesn't work you burn them at the stake
and if they're made an example of what not to do you're just not going to get
the reach anymore they're gonna back into the corners and say okay this is a risk-averse organization you've got to
lower the risk of failure whatever that means in your organization and for us it meant doing small things Chris made a
great point about start with something small it's gotta I had three children you know with your children you trust
them with small things and then over time you trust them with bigger things it actually works very similarly in an
organization trusts people with small decisions gained some come
and momentum and then you can move up to larger decisions getting the impediments
to innovation out of the way lowering the gatekeeping is also a huge part of
creating an innovative culture a culture that actually breeds innovation Jeff
Bezos says famously in our shareholder letters that he believes Amazon is one
of the best companies in which to fail what a great thing for a CEO to say can
you as the IT leader or can you get a business partner to say the same thing
to your organization because we all know from high school or primary school
science to actually invent an experiment there has to be failure and we've got to
learn that within organizations if we want to try learn and grow then the
third thing security I know some people might think I was coca-cola you know
you're not a financial institution you don't worry about security for coca-cola brand image corporate image is huge our
CEO said to me please do not destroy 100 30 seconds when it took us 130 years to
build because of a consumer data breach or some you know issue in market or
defacing of websites which you know being a large brand was we were constantly hacked and attacked so making
security everyone's responsibility bursting versus making it a team over here that everybody passes through was
the biggest thing we had to learn so we launched a security training program for everyone
ensuring transparency and auditability for the senior leadership so they knew when I moved to the new product

audit the head of technical of course so the guy that owns the ingredients in their

embarking on so but making that transparent to leadership so they know
where you're headed so those are my three things that begin your
transformation journey build agility to respond to opportunities by creating
some technical flexibility remove your barriers to innovation in a secure
environment no one's going to let you do any of that if you can't convince them
that it's a secure environment and that sets the stage for transformation so we

good morning everyone I'd like to first introduce my colleague Karim who is the program lead on
powershift Kareem has a history of working in EDF in business transformation and change and has worked
exclusively on partial for me for the last year and a half and Chris Regan so Chris Regan heads up a business

running our trading desk for many years and recently stepped into innovation so
today we're going to take you through the disruption that's coming into the energy industry and what we've done it
EDF to face that in the decentralization of energy and then we'll show our journey with AWS and our power shift
platform ok so just a little bit about a company first so we're actually the UK's
largest producer of low carbon electricity something we're proud of we've got a large presence in both the B
to the business-to-business and business-to-consumer energy supply business and we're also built adding to
our new killer fleet so many of you will be aware of the project we've got going on in key point c sets it's one of the
largest construction projects in Europe at the moment so yes that's that's an overview of the company cute so to start
I'd like to roll back in time to the 27th of March 2001 which was very poignant day in the energy industry
because it was the launch of the way the electricity market still functions today it was called the new electricity
trading arrangements and it was very much based around the way that our grid was set up back then so he had big power
stations EDF has a number of nuclear power stations we operate but there was also coal power stations and combined
cycle gas turbines or CC GTS and and the job of our operator automatic
transmission system operator National Grid was essentially to balance supply and demand and they did this through
moving those big power stations around so it was mainly to start with the big coal power stations there circa 500
megawatts in size and they would say ok I need a little bit more I need to be a little bit less and they would move
those power stations around and people like myself who were in the utilities that were operating those power stations
would essentially balance our position with the amazing spreadsheet so if you fast forward to where we are
now in 2018 the coal units assigned to switch off I don't know if any of you
